etymology.description: pictogram: inverted 子 (newborn) with three lower lines representing amniotic fluid or hair.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts an upside-down newborn emerging, with trailing lines suggesting flowing fluid or hair. The imagery naturally extends to senses of unfolding, opening out, and dispersing.

examples.chinese: 风起时(風起時)，乌云㐬而散(烏雲㐬而散)。
examples.pinyin: Fēng qǐ shí, wūyún shū ér sàn.
examples.english: When the wind rises, the dark clouds open up and disperse.

examples.chinese: 清晨(清晨)，花穗在微风中渐次㐬(花穗在微風中漸次㐬)。
examples.pinyin: Qīngchén, huāsuì zài wēifēng zhōng jiàncì shū.
examples.english: At dawn, the flower tassels gradually open in the breeze.

examples.chinese: 将锁解下(將鎖解下)，门扉自㐬(門扉自㐬)。
examples.pinyin: Jiāng suǒ jiě xià, ménfēi zì shū.
examples.english: Once the lock was undone, the door panels opened by themselves.
